note.body:
Sorry for taking a while to get back.  I'd intended to dig deeper on this problem over the weekend but we ended up with a prolonged power outage due to storms here local.

I've narrowed the problem down more and it seems to only show up for me on my laptop (which has an Nvidia 1060 Max-Q board in the traditional Optimus layout) when the Nvidia driver is engaged via PRIME.  The driver version in use is 430.26 from the Graphics Drivers PPA here: https://launchpad.net/~graphics-drivers/+archive/ubuntu/ppa

It does NOT show up when using the Intel driver and Intel GPU on the laptop NOR the AMD HD 4830 using the stock drivers (K)Ubuntu 18.04.2 on my old Sandybridge system.  This appears to be an Nvidia specific problem.  (figures)  It also didn't show up in GIMP 2.10.8 on the same hardware but the drivers had changed since then as well as GIMP.  It doesn't show with GIMP 2.10.12 on Windows 10 on the same hardware when using an HDMI external monitor (which forces the Nvidia GPU instead of Intel I believe).

events.target_title: Wrong focus window via XGetInputFocus when input focus is on Activity
Wrong focus window via XGetInputFocus when input focus is on Activity

note.body:
Thanks for the explanation.

> Is this with a Xorg or Wayland session?

This is with Xorg session.

> Yes, even further, they are not windows like Wine is.

Out of curiosity, what are they exactly?

> In theory you should at least receive some type of FocusOut event

Yes. We did. Pressing Super key to open Activity View got the following events:

```
0028:fixme:event:X11DRV_FocusOut win 0x10052 xwin 5c00001 detail=NotifyAncestor mode=NotifyGrab
0028:fixme:event:X11DRV_FocusIn win 0x10052 xwin 5c00001 detail=NotifyAncestor mode=NotifyUngrab
0028:fixme:event:X11DRV_FocusOut win 0x10052 xwin 5c00001 detail=NotifyNonlinear mode=NotifyGrab
0028:fixme:event:X11DRV_FocusOut win 0x10052 xwin 5c00001 detail=NotifyNonlinear mode=NotifyWhileGrabbed
```

Our current plan is to treat input focus as lost after FocusOut NotifyGrab and NotifyWhileGrabbed.

Although XGetInputFocus is just the counterpart of XSetInputFocus. When keyboard is grabbed by WM, shouldn't we call XSetInputFocus as well to update the input focus window? Just for its behavior to be correct?

events.target_title: extend rsvg-convert to emit CairoScript data
extend rsvg-convert to emit CairoScript data

note.body:
Thank you for taking care on this. In fact, originally I was thinking XML output could be re-rendered into some graphics, but I found it is not possible.

https://lists.cairographics.org/archives/cairo/2019-January/028829.html

Yes, the lack of good example how to replay CairoScript is an issue. The sample programs, csi-bind, csi-exec, csi-replay, csi-trace (csi is CairoScript interpreter) are included in the Cairo source package:

https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/cairo/cairo/tree/master/util/cairo-script

But they are not built by default, even if configured with "--enable-interpreter=yes". Manual invocation "make -C util/cairo-script csi-exec csi-replay csi-trace" is needed to build them. I'm afraid cairo-bind has been broken.

Once csi-exec is built, please try some examples in util/cairo-script/examples/. If csi-exec is invoked as "./csi-exec ./examples/dragon.cs", new PNG file "out.png" is generated which includes a dragon curve.

Maybe some people wonder "who determined the name of out.png? I don't give that". Yes, it is determined in dragon.cs (at the end of script). I guess, some people would complain "I want to have a tool with an interface like ImageMagick, like, csi-convert input.cs output.{xml|png|svg|pdf|eps}".

Fully I agree, but there is no such in Cairo source package, at present. Maybe I should contribute something like that. If you think "this patch should be revisited after having such nice tool", please postpone the consideration whether this MR could be applied or should not be applied.

events.target_title: tracker-miner-fs brings system to its knees when indexing - scope for deduplicating hardlinked files?
Rearrange / Sort icons

note.body:
Yes, being able to maintain a desired position for desktop icons is the primary requirement, as people do like to position things in specific places... but when it gets out of hand and folks want to start from scratch, being able to "reset" that layout on demand is very useful.

Yes, you can open the directory in Files (Nautilus), but explicitly requesting a sort order there does not affect the desktop, even when you want it to.

Desktop user environments where the ability to both custom position, and re-order on demand by name, type, date etc. include:
* Windows
* macOS
* KDE
* LXDE 

There appears to have been a decision at one point to completely remove desktop icon support (I understand it was originally part of nautilus, but this introduced some structural challenges?) from Gnome, and then to add it back begrudgingly, but as part of an extension to the gnome-shell. Users, myself included, are accustomed to having the desktop behave similarly to a folder, with the exception that icon positions are remembered until they're explicitly reset and/or the user opts for automatic sorting.

Whilst hand held / touch screen devices (Android, iOS etc.) might have their desktops/homescreens statically assigned, larger devices such as notebooks and desktop computers aren't generally expected to be as static - particularly when the likelihood that different desktop dimensions may be encountered as a user goes between inbuilt and external displays (such as with a notebook computer).

note.body:
Thanks for checking the log.

I signed up for premium service for my mail.com email address (to get access to SMTP/IMAP servers).  Sending emails with attachments from my mail.com email address works fine with the latest version of Evolution on Fedora 29.  

I can send emails with attachments from my Comcast email address with Evolution 3.28.5 (Fedora 28) but not 3.30.1 or 3.30.5 (Fedora 29).  I can also send emails with attachments from my Comcast email using Thunderbird on Fedora 29.  

So maybe Comcast has a faulty spam filter that is rejecting outgoing mail with attachments sent from more recent versions of Evolution.

events.target_title: Sending emails with attachments using Evolution 3.30.1 and 3.30.5

note.body:
This morning I tried sending an email with a pdf file attached using Evolution 3.28.5 from my comcast.net account to my mail.com account and it failed. So I'm now getting the same behavior from all versions of Evolution when sending an email with an attachment from my comcast.net email: the message appears to be sent (it ends up in the sent mail folder), but the recipient never gets it. I first became aware of the emails with attachments not getting to the recipient when I tried sending an email with attached file to someone else and he didn't get it (on April 23). I saved three equivalent messages in my sent email folder to mbox files. The three messages were sent from my comcast.net account to my mail.com account using Evolution 3.28.5, Evolution 3.30.5, and Thunderbird respectively. The Thunderbird message includes the sentence "This is a multi-part message in MIME format" before the body of the message, but the Evolution messages do not include this sentence. This morning I tried sending an email with a pdf attachment from my mail.com address to my comcast.net address using both Evolution 3.30.5 and Evolution 3.28.5. Only the message sent from 3.30.5 arrived at my comcast.net address. With Thunderbird, I have no problems at all sending emails with attachments from either of my email accounts. **This is the message sent by Evolution 3.28.5 (minus the attached pdf file):** ```From x@comcast.net Thu Apr 25 09:55:17 2019 Message-ID: Subject: testing attachment with Evolution 3.28.5 From: Jason Heller To: x@mail.com Date: Thu, 25 Apr 2019 09:55:17 -0600 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="=-lLwoguyO4A3UGzSoFtrc" X-Mailer: Evolution 3.28.5 (3.28.5-2.fc28) Mime-Version: 1.0 X-Evolution-Identity: c0e91875da4cb9f5011f6f8e8f50be2dda4fbff5 X-Evolution-Fcc: folder://9a20eaa16446fb2859e6c67adb906deb2a0818b5/Sent X-Evolution-Transport: 92171a02668d0aecab259ad0eb03dd0a6b1b19e1 X-Evolution-Source: --=-lLwoguyO4A3UGzSoFtrc Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="=-YxM8otc62dKNwvi67fzB" --=-YxM8otc62dKNwvi67fzB Content-Type: text/plain Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit pdf attached --=-YxM8otc62dKNwvi67fzB Content-Type: text/html; charset="utf-8" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

events.target_title: Sending emails with attachments using Evolution 3.30.1 and 3.30.5

note.body: Email with attachment from my Comcast address to my Comcast address fails with both versions of Evolution (3.30.5 and 3.28.5); emails do end up in the sent folder.  Email with attachment from my mail.com address to my mail.com address succeeds with both versions of Evolution.

events.target_title: Sending emails with attachments using Evolution 3.30.1 and 3.30.5

note.body:
When an email with attachment fails, the recipient gets nothing.  The message is not in the junk folder.  I did try changing the SMTP settings from STARTTLS to SSL (there was no effect).

The Thunderbird message header contains the sentence "This is a multi-part message in MIME format", but the Evolution message headers (for all versions) do not contain this message.  I think that if Evolution added that sentence to the header for emails with attachments, Comcast email accounts could use Evolution to send emails with attachments.

As I stated above, I was able to use Evolution 3.28.5 to send emails with attachments earlier.  But after sending a few test emails with a .pdf attachment from my comcast.net address to mail.com address, this no longer works.  The only way to make sense of this is that as a result of these few emails, Comcast's spam filters are now classifying more of my emails as spam.  So I don't want to do any more testing, since this might classify still more of my emails as spam.

I'll be using my mail.com address for important emails from now on.  Since I am paying mail.com specifically for email service now, they will be far more likely to help if there are problems in the future.  The Comcast email address is free with Comcast cable internet, so Comcast doesn't have much motivation to help with any email problems.

events.target_title: Adding search with highlight all

note.body:
Hi @egmontkob, thanks for your in-depth explanation about the status of current infrastructure, it should help others who are interesting in this, too.

I agree it should have rework on the infra, and the long term should be done in BiDi. If there have anything I can help, please point me out where I can help with!

On the other hand, in the current situation, I also want a fast-way to support this function. I've tested with another plan which we can prevent doing any changed on current API, and may be much easier to implement:

* Export a `multi_select_text(start_col, start_row, end_col, end_row)` API to the public, which will not `deselect_all` when called, and only applied on current buffer row (auto add `m_screen->scroll_delta` to row), it will add this span to the array (as previously describe). Also, it will not affect by `deselect_all()`.

* Export a `multi_unselect_text_all()` API to the public, which will reset `multi_select_text` index to 0 (alought the span is still set in the array, but `*cell_is_multi_selected()` will apply the index.

* Add `cell_is_multi_selected(col, row)`, which will check if the `(col, row)` is inside the multi-selected array (up to the index), and if it is inside old-fashion `m_selection_resolved`, too. (if coord is in multi_select_array or cord == m_selection_resolved)

* Change `draw_rows()` behavior, it should distinguish current cell selected difference of `m_selection_resolved` and `multi_select_text` by using `cell_is_multi_selected` & `cell_is_selected`, then given different background color & foreground color (thus we can know which is highlight, and which is current searched on)

* Export `set/get_multi_select_[bg/fg]_color()` for changing multi select color.

In this way, user then can done the highlight, and handle scrolling by itself without current VTE infra for search/match:

apply highlight
```python
text, attr = vterm.get_text()
lines = text.split('\n')

# Reset highlight selection
vterm.multi_unselect_text_all()

SEARCH = 'VTE'
LEN = len(SEARCH)
for row, line in enumerate(lines):
    if SEARCH in row:
        index = -1
        while True:
            index = line.find(SEARCH, index + 1)
            if index == -1:
                break
            vterm.multi_select_text(index, row, index + LEN, row)
```

handle text-[scrolled/modified/inserted/deleted]
```python
vterm.connect('text-scrolled', [previous highlight])
```

tested on Guake
![Selection_968](/uploads/4a582414ca86c2d9937db0c83f9d75ab/Selection_968.png)

How do you think about this?

events.target_title: Move undo to in-app notification

note.body: I think what's cancellable is the commit to the remote server, not the actions themselves. These actions (move/archive/delete) are not irreversibly destructive, they are undoable. Otherwise, the user may think that if they miss their five seconds, they cannot undo their decision, which they actually can.

events.target_title: Move undo to in-app notification

note.body:
Well currently the notification is showing during AND after the commit. This follows the previous implementation, where the undo button would cancel the sync before the commit, and would unmove the message after the commit. 

Theoretically, I agree that the sync/commit is cancellable and following the commit, the action is revertible. So I guess the ideal would be to show a 'moving' notification with 'cancel' button, and then show a 'moved' notification with 'undo' button. 

However, I would argue - if I'm understanding this correctly - that this is the result of the underlying IMAP protocol, not the intention of the user. The user intends to move one or messages (and I don't think either of these actions are destructive, they are all move actions: to a folder [any, archive, trash]). If the underlying protocol was POP3, the command and the commit would be the same thing. The user moved the message, what we are committing is the sync. 

Isn't it more confusing for the users to figure out why it takes time for the message to move, that they can cancel the move, and then afterwards they can undo it. All they care is to undo what they did in the first place, and for them, that's just a move action, not start async -> finish_async -> start_undo_async -> finish_undo_async.

However, following the first paragraph, the notification may/does repop after the commit and I'm not happy with this part of my implementation. I would have preferred to keep it up until the timeout following the commit, but I could not figure out a simple way to implement it without a lot of changes.

events.target_title: Marshalling of GPtrArray broken

note.body:
It seems that this issue occurs because, when GPtrArrays are marshalled into GJS arrays, `gjs_array_from_carray_internal()` considers in some cases GPtrArrays as arrays of structures instead of arrays of pointers.

## Investigations

This behavior can be observed by setting a breakpoint at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/blob/1.57.2/gi/arg.cpp#L2327, and by executing `gjs> imports.gi.NM.Client.new(null).get_devices()[0].get_ip4_config().get_addresses()`.

The execution stops twice, first for the call of `get_devices()` for the conversion of a GPtrArray of NMDevice:

```
2327	            GIInfoType info_type = g_base_info_get_type (interface_info);
(gdb) next
2330	                 info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_UNION) &&
(gdb) call g_type_name(g_registered_type_info_get_g_type(interface_info))
$1 = (const gchar *) 0x7f36cdfba974 "NMDevice"
(gdb) call info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_STRUCT
$2 = false
(gdb) call info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_UNION
$3 = false
(gdb) call !g_type_info_is_pointer(param_info)
$4 = true
(gdb) print array
$5 = (gpointer) 0x560f2f2a4e90
```

And a second time for the call of `get_addresses()` for the conversion of a GPtrArray of NMIPAddress:

```
2327	            GIInfoType info_type = g_base_info_get_type (interface_info);
(gdb) next
2330	                 info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_UNION) &&
(gdb) call g_type_name(g_registered_type_info_get_g_type(interface_info))
$6 = (const gchar *) 0x7f36cdfc3fe5 "NMIPAddress"
(gdb) call info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_STRUCT
$7 = true
(gdb) call info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_UNION
$8 = false
(gdb) call !g_type_info_is_pointer(param_info)
$9 = true
(gdb) print array
$10 = (gpointer) 0x560f2f294ac0
```

An error occurs on this second conversion: Because both `info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_STRUCT` and `!g_type_info_is_pointer(param_info)` are `true`, the GPtrArray of NMIPAddress is interpreted as an array of structures instead of an array of pointers.

This can be seen in the debug output, with `GJS_VERBOSE_ENABLE_MARSHAL` enabled, where the NMIPAddress is directly read at `0x560f2f294ac0` which is the address of the first pointer of the GPtrArray instead of being read at the location pointed by this pointer:

```
   JS G FUNC: Converting GArgument array to JS::Value
   JS G FUNC: Converting GArgument interface to JS::Value
   JS G FUNC: gtype of INTERFACE is NMIPAddress
    JS G BXD: Wrapping struct IPAddress 0x560f2f294ac0 with JSObject
     JS G NS: Found info type STRUCT for 'IPAddress' in namespace 'NM'
    JS G BXD: Defined class for IPAddress (NMIPAddress), prototype 0x7f36ce2b3af0, JSClass 0x7f36dc5b1fc0, in object 0x7f36ce2b3130

(gjs:18301): libnm-CRITICAL **: 11:14:37.018: nm_ip_address_new: assertion 'family == AF_INET || family == AF_INET6' failed
[boxed prototype of GIName:NM.IPAddress jsobj@0x7f36ce2b3b50]
```

This assertion error may indicate that the NMIPAddress structure read contains invalid data, because:

* This error is raised by `nm_ip_address_new()` if the value of `family` is invalid (see https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/blob/1.10.6/libnm-core/nm-setting-ip-config.c#L210)
* And this value of `family` is obtained by reading the value of the NMIPAddress passed to `nm_ip_address_dup()` (see https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/blob/1.10.6/libnm-core/nm-setting-ip-config.c#L380)
* Which is the `copy_func` declared for NMIPAddress (see https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/blob/1.10.6/libnm-core/nm-setting-ip-config.c#L180)

The difference of behavior between the conversion of NMDevice and NMIPAddress can be explained by the following simplified excerpt of the `NM-1.0.gir` file, generated by libnm, where we can see that NMDevice is declared as a `class` and where NMIPAddress is declared as a `record`:

```xml
<namespace name="NM" version="1.0" shared-library="libnm.so.0" c:identifier-prefixes="NM" c:symbol-prefixes="nm">
  <class name="Client" c:symbol-prefix="client" c:type="NMClient" parent="GObject.Object" glib:type-name="NMClient" glib:get-type="nm_client_get_type"   glib:type-struct="ClientClass">
    <method name="get_devices" c:identifier="nm_client_get_devices">
      <return-value transfer-ownership="none">
        <array name="GLib.PtrArray" c:type="const GPtrArray*">
          <type name="Device"/>
        </array>
      </return-value>
    </method>
  </class>
  <class name="Device" c:symbol-prefix="device" c:type="NMDevice" parent="Object" abstract="1" glib:type-name="NMDevice" glib:get-type="nm_device_get_type" glib:type-struct="DeviceClass">
  </class>

  <class name="IPConfig" c:symbol-prefix="ip_config" c:type="NMIPConfig" parent="Object" abstract="1" glib:type-name="NMIPConfig"   glib:get-type="nm_ip_config_get_type" glib:type-struct="IPConfigClass">
    <method name="get_addresses" c:identifier="nm_ip_config_get_addresses">
      <return-value transfer-ownership="none">
        <array name="GLib.PtrArray" c:type="GPtrArray*">
          <type name="IPAddress"/>
        </array>
      </return-value>
    </method>
  </class>
  <record name="IPAddress" c:type="NMIPAddress" glib:type-name="NMIPAddress" glib:get-type="nm_ip_address_get_type" c:symbol-prefix="ip_address">
  </record>
</namespace>
```

## Resolution proposition

One way of fixing this issue is to consider the array type in `gjs_array_from_carray_internal()` so that we can avoid treating array elements as structures instead of pointers when the array is a `GPtrArray`.

The patched version will then give us the following outputs:

```
2328	            GIInfoType info_type = g_base_info_get_type (interface_info);
(gdb) next
2332	                 info_type == GI_INFO_TYPE_UNION) &&
(gdb) call g_type_name(g_registered_type_info_get_g_type(interface_info))
$1 = (const gchar *) 0x7f67c86c3fe5 "NMIPAddress"
(gdb) call array_type != GI_ARRAY_TYPE_PTR_ARRAY
$2 = false
(gdb) print array
$3 = (gpointer) 0x562bde3c6aa0
(gdb) print sizeof(gpointer)
$4 = 8
(gdb) x/8xb 0x562bde3c6aa0
0x562bde3c6aa0:	0xa0	0x21	0x2d	0xde	0x2b	0x56	0x00	0x00
```

```
   JS G FUNC: Converting GArgument array to JS::Value
   JS G FUNC: Converting GArgument interface to JS::Value
   JS G FUNC: gtype of INTERFACE is NMIPAddress
    JS G BXD: Wrapping struct IPAddress 0x562bde2d21a0 with JSObject
     JS G NS: Found info type STRUCT for 'IPAddress' in namespace 'NM'
    JS G BXD: Defined class for IPAddress (NMIPAddress), prototype 0x7f67c89b3af0, JSClass 0x7f67d6ccafc0, in object 0x7f67c89b3130
[boxed instance wrapper GIName:NM.IPAddress jsobj@0x7f67c89b3b50 native@0x562bde388860]
```

This time, the NMIPAddress is read at the correct address, `0x562bde2d21a0`, which is the address pointed by `0x562bde3c6aa0`, the first element of the GPtrArray.

Also, please note that the previously submitted patch was also fixing this issue because it had, in the end, the same effect on the conversion of a GPtrArray than the one proposed here.
However this new proposition is less impacting that the previous one.

## Resolution proposition tests

Finally, about the tests: The existing tests covering the marhalling of `GPtrArray` are implemented in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/blob/1.57.2/installed-tests/js/testGIMarshalling.js#L279.

These tests are passing before and after the proposed patch because:

* These are only covering the marshalling of GPtrArray configured with `element-type utf8` (see https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gobject-introspection/blob/1.60.1/tests/gimarshallingtests.c#L2187)
* And because GPtrArray with `GI_TYPE_TAG_UTF8` elements are treated differently than the ones with `GI_TYPE_TAG_INTERFACE` elements (see https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/blob/1.57.2/gi/arg.cpp#L2355)

Unfortunately it does not look like tests can easily be added to cover this fix, without having to add new functions in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gobject-introspection/blob/1.60.1/tests/gimarshallingtests.c.

GtkCalendar can't be used in a multilingual application
GtkCalendar can't be used in a multilingual application

note.body:
It may not be explicitly supported, but it turns out that GTK is an ideal environment for a multilingual application. All our applications are multilingual, which is especially straightforward when using GtkBuilder.
Text objects that need to be translated can be marked, and the text substituted at the moment of language selection. The code required to implement this is a fraction of that formerly required, when our programs were Windows based. The calendar is the only nuisance that we have so far encountered - an owner drawn widget is currently needed.

This bug has just bitten me, and it was quite difficult for me to find the cause.
Maybe someone with appropriate permissions could add an entry to https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/Rygel/FAQ, sth. like this:

## Rygel does not list all my files

This can happen if Rygel cannot create a thumbnail or otherwise extract metadata from a file; for example because the file is broken, or because the file is currently being downloaded. The file will be placed on an internal blacklist and will not be displayed by Rygel.

To clear the blacklist, stop Rygel, then remove the cache file `~/.cache/rygel/media-export.db`, and start Rygel again.

note.body:
Sorry for the delay in replying.

Here's an example: With the current behavior, if I create a task that
repeats every 1 week, due this Friday, and mark it completed a day late
(Saturday), it will be rescheduled for the following Friday, one week
from the original due date.

With my proposed alternate behavior enabled, the task would be
rescheduled for the following Saturday. Or, if I mark it completed a
day early (Thursday), it is resceduled for the next Thursday. One week
from completion date, as opposed to due date.

note.body:
Hello Mike,

Attached are the answers to your questions.  It is not that I am new to programming, I just do not know to go about debugging that.  Whenever I try to do something to debug the situation it starts working again.

The only command that might cause this error is:
```
echo "$PATH" | sed 's,:, ,g'
```
that should separate the PATH variable at the ':' character and that should never generate this kind of errors, but it does repeatably.

Then I tried to modify the script and add some echo commands:  
I copied the script /usr/bin/gparted to another directory and the problem was gone again.

Then I modified the startup script in the original location before line 95:
```
#
# Search PATH to determine if systemctl program can be found
# and if appropriate daemon is running.
#
HAVE_SYSTEMCTL=n
echo "$PATH"
myvar=$(echo "$PATH" | sed 's,:, ,g')
echo "My variable myvar >$myvar<"
```

and I get the error message isolated:
```
<my computer> # /usr/bin/gparted
/sbin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/sbin:/root/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/lib/mit/sbin
/usr/bin/gparted: line 96: /usr/bin/sed: Permission denied
My variable myvar ><
```

then I tried to execute the command with 'sed' at the command line
```
<my computer> # echo $PATH | sed 's,:, ,g'
/sbin /usr/sbin /usr/local/sbin /root/bin /usr/local/bin /usr/bin /bin /usr/lib/mit/sbin
```
and it worked fine. 

My conclusion is that somehow the script has problems at the position it executes, but I still do not know which ones and I have no clue what the error could be and how to pin down the problem.

kind regards
Franz
 
the information you asked for
```
<myself@mycomputer:~> head -1 /usr/bin/gparted
#!/bin/sh
<myself@mycomputer:~> ls -li /bin/sh /bin/bash
258901 -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 1012552  9. Okt 2018  /bin/bash

note.body:
Please never disable this feature by default, are really that many people having an issue with this all of a sudden?  
The proper way to solve this is to give people an option to turn it off.

events.target_title: gitg very slow showing commits with hundreds of files

note.body:
Hi @gaurav1999 ,
Regarding the fact that is actually a practical situation or not: I'm using gitg to explore the history of a commercial software product that contains 200k files. A checkin that changes 200 files is actually very common in that repository (and 200 files over 200k is just 0.1% of the files of the repo!).

Indeed there are checkins that e.g. mass change the name of something and that contain like 6000 files.

So in conclusion: very large commits are absolutely a practical situation in large projects IMO :)

note.body: Thank you for reacting and taking user feedback seriously. So many users out there but hardly anyone makes the effort or is able to report bugs - that's actually a serious problem for itself, right? As a "simple user" it's not always easy to be heard in the free software realm (I know, proprietary SW companies sh.. on their users). Nonetheless, this issue tracker isn't just a "feel-good" area - I have to make my complaints and their importance clear. As a veteran sw-developer I have felt the pain of endless high-priority, immediate-fix bug reports. But that is what this tool is about - not to make you feel comfy. Thank you for your efforts, I really appreciate the software you are building here.

note.body:
Hello Philip,
sadly, I do have to reply - some things seem to be misunderstood, and I'll try to straighten them out for you and perhaps the greater public.

> ... Georges isn't currently paid ...

I don't know who is working on this piece of software and I don't *need* to know. 

You see, this Issue Tracker is a kind of abstraction layer between me - a user - and someone out there who might be programming - the developer.

This is all about the Program - not about me, not about you, and not about Georges. A program and it's bugs, it's functionality, what it does and doesn't do, and what someone would like to have. These **Issues** are all collected here and can and should be reviewed, analyzed, categorized, given a priority, and so on. So that when someone comes along who can and will work on this program, he knows what must be done first, second and so on.

> ...so it's inappropriate for you to make such claims on his free time.

If you understand my last paragraph, you'll see how foolish it was to accuse me in this way.

> ...If you feel it requires a high priority and timely due date, then maybe you can find a contractor ...

Well, Well. If I feel it requires a high priority and timely due date, **then I should do exactly what I did: put it in this database.** Nothing else.

Let me Quote the GNOME project: **"The GNOME Project is a diverse international community which involves hundreds of contributors, many of whom are volunteers.** Well I'm just a user, but I'm putting time and effort into making GNOME better. Not just hacking on with some workarounds that'll just fix my problem. This is my role as a user. 

I didn't expect thanks. I was just doing what I could to make GNOME better. I certainly didn't expect this kind of arrogant attack. Again, I'll quote GNOME:

> **GNOME is a friendly and welcoming community.**

events.target_title: How to know if  the client has received an one chunk under chunked transfer ?

note.body:
I'll let explain the background a little. I'm working on a DASH player and my request is from a feature, called Low Latency. You can find out more about the distribution chain for this feature in the link below.

https://blogs.akamai.com/2018/10/best-practices-for-ultra-low-latency-streaming-using-chunked-encoded-and-chunk-transferred-cmaf.html

Basically adaptive players, DASH or HLS etc, should be able to measure maximum network throughput but we can not do that by measuring data rate over an one request under 'chunked transfer'. Because the data rate is unlikely to be representative of the maximum network throughput available.
So I think this could be achieved by measuring data rate of each HTTP 1.1 chunk between a client and an edge server because each HTTP 1.1 chunk will be sent at max network speed. This way using javascript fetch API already has been being discussed in DASH industry. What do you think about it?

note.body:
Hi! Thanks for your response and re-organization!

S3 is suspend-to-RAM (suspend) (see [here](https://onlinehelp.ncr.com/Retail/Workstations/7613/HTML/Topics/UserGuide/5.%20Power%20Management/3-ACPI%20Sleep%20States%20(S0%20-%20S5).htm?TocPath=Features%7CPower%20Management%7C_____2) for more details).  The "S" means "STATE" as in "Sleep State" (this is from ACPI power specs).

I can also confirm that re-starting the process works, so I'm creating a workaround by way of a systemd "kill-and-restart" script to be executed on resume every time, restarting the process if it's running.

Cheers!

note.body:
@Jehan 
> * When the language is set to 'System Language' in Preferences (OS is set to English), you cannot save or export any file.
> * When it is set to 'English_US' (or anything else?), you can export/save normally.

^^ This is correct! Hopefully, the following will provide some clarification:


The issue started a while back when I upgraded from (I believe) 2.8 to the newest version 2.10.12. I did some troubleshooting before trying posting on this forum (see below). The research I found indicated that there were some issues when upgrading and the files were conflicting with each other. 

Links I used for trying to solve the issue:

https://www.gimpusers.com/forums/gimp-user/20616-2-10-won-t-export-or-save-in-jpg-png

I did the following troubleshooting in the following forum (see the last comment; I've also added it as a quote):

https://www.gimp-forum.net/Thread-No-Option-in-2-10-to-Export-as-jpg-jpeg-png?pid=7917#pid7917

> Reading your other posts as well. 
> 
> Open Raster .ora is a multi-layer format that uses png compression. No png - no .ora
> 
> Your Gimp 2.10.0 installation not working.
> 
> In the past, when you used Gimp 2.8, did you install any plugins into the base C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\ file structure. Some "plugin installers" do that.  When Gimp 2.10 uninstalls Gimp 2.8 these are left behind and might affect working.
> 
> Same with the 2.8 Gimp profile C:\Users\your-name\.gimp-2.8\ That correctly remains but some files are copied to the new Gimp 2.10 profile.
> 
> If you want to get Gimp 2.10 running, try
> 1. Use the windows uninstaller to uninstall Gimp 2.10
> 2. If any of C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\ remains delete it.
> 3. Disable the Gimp 2.8 profile, rename or move out to a backup folder.
> 4. Now install Gimp 2.10, run it to make a default Gimp 2.10 profile.
> 
> ..and if it does not work, something seriously wrong with your Windows installation.


^^ This didn't work for me. That said, after I did these steps, I posted my comment on this forum. **Eventually I changed the language to English** and the saving/exporting problem went away!

Also, I'm pleased to report that after installing the latest version (2.10.12), this issue is not present.

events.target_title: Crash when using with Sourcetree DIFF in 3.20: Cannot import gi / Cannot import GTK+: The specific module could not be found

note.body:
I can verify that the workaround from @llaniewski works. Actually only `C:\Program Files (x86)\Meld\lib` is required in `$PATH` if you call the binary with full path. However, as mentioned in #143:

> Adding to path directory with `meld.exe` is quite risky idea - it contains a lot of DLLs with common names: `python27.dll`, `libwinpthread-1.dll`, `libjpeg-8.dll`, `libintl-8.dll`, `libgio-2.0-0.dll`, And many others.

There are simply too many source for path modification, and my path has been too crowded, so I prefer the solution by @florisla that copies the required DLL, with one modification: instead of copying the file, I made a symbolic link with [mklink](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/mklink):

```cmd
mklink libgirepository-1.0-1.dll lib\libgirepository-1.0-1.dll
```

events.target_title: tracker-extract causes system lock-up due to 100% CPU and memory usage

note.body:
Thanks - I just emailed you the debug file (I sometimes end up in the spam folder at Gmail, so might want to check that if you didn't receive it).

In the log file, the relevant stuff starts at May 05 09:45:52. At 09:46:01 you'll see "Received signal:15" - that's me killing tracker-extract because it's consuming almost all of the memory (if I don't the computer will lock up).

The tracker-extract process restarts automatically after it's being killed, so every "Terminated" from there on is me killing the process right before it exhausts the memory.

Finally I kill off tracker-extract repeatedly whilst alt-tabbing to another window to kill the parent processes as well to prevent tracker-extract from starting again. :)

events.target_title: tracker-extract causes system lock-up due to 100% CPU and memory usage

note.body:
Hm, I added .trackerignore to ~/Downloads ("touch .trackerignore") and a few other fairly large directories, and then ran tracker reset --hard, logged out and back in. Still, it exhausts all available memory and I can see in journalctl that it's attempting to crawl subdirectories and files within ~/Downloads. Just to be clear on the .trackerignore:

-rw-rw-r-- 1 vegard vegard 0 May  6 14:18 .trackerignore

The files being treated as text files are probably scenery files, aircrafts etc for my flight simulator - I tend to unpack them in ~/Downloads before moving them into their respective places.

Any ideas why it seems to be ignoring the ignore file :-)

Anyway - until a magic solution appears I'll just kill all the tracker processes in my login script. :-)

Let me know if you guys need any more input from me (or to test a fix or something).

events.target_title: Go to previous/next image using arrow keys

note.body:
Just started to use gThumb which I think is great and super useful! I am also surprised by the choice of shortcuts which feels pretty unnatural because it's different from similar gnome apps (eog and photos). 
 
>  This may be because the arrow keys are used to tweak the slider values when editing an image. For example, when changing the brightness of an image, you can use the arrow keys to move the slider back and forth.

It does not seem incompatible : when editing the image you need to focus on the setting you want to change so you can't go to the next image anyway (from what I have experienced I may be wrong).
>  Arrow keys are used to scroll the image when it doesn't fit the viewer space

Indeed... but when you zoom in and navigate in the image, I feel you would rather use the mouse/trackpad rather than the keyboard, which is tedious.

I would add that I was also mistaken by the two-finger scrolling implementation: I'd rather expect to zoom in/out than go the next/previous image. It is not very convenient anyway because it scrolls too fast (on my computer at least).

Would you guys reconsider these decisions ?

events.target_title: Prefer Reply-To from To/Cc in Group Reply
Prefer Reply-To from To/Cc in Group Reply

note.body:
Hi Milan,

Yes, my evolution is localized, just changed to en_US as you suggested.

I would like to point out that I just updated my ubuntu installation in order to check if the transition from 3.30 to 3.32 would make any difference, therefore Evolution version now is: 3.32.1-2

When I reply to the email I usually press the Group Reply button on the upper part of Evolution Main Window.
Pressing the Group Reply the new message "To:" is still my email address, not the Gitlab email address that is present in the header.

Using the Ctrl+R or Reply button as you suggested, then Reply privately gives me the correct email address in the "To:" field.

- If I "Ctrl+R" => Reply Privately => The correct email address appears in the "To:" field
- If I "Ctrl+R" => Reply to All => My email address appears in the "To:" field
- If I "Ctrl+R" => Reply to List => My email address appears in the "To:" field

I had the assumption (obviously wrong) that:
- Reply Privately would send the email only to the person that wrote the message on gitlab,
- Reply to All would send an email to the person that wrote the message AND publish to gitlab my reply
- Reply to List would publish to gitlab my reply

The behaviour observed pressing the "Reply to All" and "Reply to List" is in any case wrong because pressing the "Send" button would mean that I am sending an email to myself, not to All or to a List.

Andrea

note.body:
Hi Milan,

thank you for your reply.
You provided the solution in your last message.

basically I configured gitlab as "Dedicated email address" as explained in https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/incoming_email.html

In my first post I mentioned that I receive the email as 

`From: GitLab <gitlab_email@domain.com>` 

and not as

[incoming+42a3105664635d154c4a930f9e163b9d@gitlab.gnome.org](mailto:incoming+42a3105664635d154c4a930f9e163b9d@gitlab.gnome.org)

Your hesitation to believe that I configured an account with the address incoming+42a3105664635d154c4a930f9e163b9d@gitlab.gnome.org is correct. I just configured during the tests the account gitlab_email@domain.com in order to see if the emails are sent and received correctly.

Removing the account gitlab_email@domain.com from evolution permits the correct evaluation of the TO: address.

I think that the issue can be closed for this particular case that I was facing.
Just a final thought... it is correct that if I have an email configured with the same address it is removed and the original recipient is used instead?

thank you
Andrea

events.target_title: Prefer Reply-To from To/Cc in Group Reply

note.body:
Hi Milan,

Sorry if my first post was misleading. I just intended that the email address is just that one.

Regarding my last question I try to explain using the data from my first post.

This is what I got as raw email message:

    From: GitLab <gitlab_email@domain.com>
    Reply-To: Projects / ShinyProject <gitlab_email@domain.com>
    To: <my_email_address@domain.com>


When I press the reply button and both accounts From and To fields are configured in evolution the new email that is created is filled with:

    To: <my_email_address@domain.com>

instead I would expect that the new email would contain:

    To: <gitlab_email@domain.com>

I understand that both email address are configured as account of Evolution, but... given the fact that the From and To fields are determined I think that the right choice would be to swap them.

It is not a big deal for me, I understood what was causing the strange behavior in my setup. I am just pointing out that *maybe* the correct behavior is to swap the two fields if both accounts are setup in evolution. 
If you think that it is better to keep the current behavior instead, the issue can be closed.

thank you
Andrea

events.target_title: Saving files to desktop (from e.g. gedit) is very slow

note.body:
I do use git, yes, but I would rather avoid installing the dependencies and so on. What I ended up doing was downloading the two changed files (`desktopManager.js` and `fileItem.js`) and replacing the installed Ubuntu versions (in `/usr/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano`), then logging out and in.

I can report:
- The log messages no longer appear.
- The file *does not* save any more quickly with the changes in !135.

Something I did not notice previously:
- With the Ubuntu version, all icons disappear momentarily when the file is saved.
- With the new code, this happens twice or three times (varies).

Finally, since reporting the downstream Ubuntu bug, I cleaned my desktop by moving a large number of files into a folder. I notice that the delay in saving the file is short when my desktop is mostly empty. When I create a large number of additional files (something like `touch {{a..z},{A..Z},{0..99}}.txt`) then the delay increases to several seconds. Again, this occurs both with and without the changes in !135.

events.target_title: Saving files to desktop (from e.g. gedit) is very slow

note.body:
I don't understand why that process of desktop icon grid recreation must occur _before_ the file save operation in gedit (or whatever other application is trying to write a file to the desktop) is allowed to finish—especially when other applications are maximized and the desktop is not visible.

Can't it occur afterwards, or asynchronously?

note.body:
Just a question: Is there a way to get input events un-queued and uncompressed, if needed? 

For a real-time audio application it is problematic that input events are synchronized to the screen refresh as it will introduce a 0 to 16 ms jitter to the input events.
It might also be undesirable for networked gaming.

note.body:
Hmm, upon further testing with the Flatpak version and comparing it to the natively-installed version, it seems to be an issue with gstreamer specifically rather than gnome-podcasts.

Within gdb run I actually get this now:
```
Thread 30 "aqueue:src" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
[Switching to Thread 0x7fffd0498700 (LWP 15320)]
0x00007ffff4f310eb in gst_audio_buffer_map ()
   from /usr/lib/libgstaudio-1.0.so.0
```

Since the Flatpak seemingly relies on `org.freedesktop.Platform.html5-codecs`which doesn't demonstrate this bug.

I'll try to git clone and build the latest source instead of 0.4.6 and see if it still shows the bug.

note.body: Ah, I think I've finally isolated the bug! I reinstalled my OS and was unable to reproduce it afterward, but then I installed gst-libav and started having the crash again. It seems that the crash occurs ONLY when gst-libav (1.16.0-1) is installed. Uninstalling gst-libav makes GNOME Podcasts work again.

events.target_title: Trying to change playback speed causes a crash

note.body:
re: the actual file that triggers this issue with gst-libav, it seems to be a .m2a file that gets generated when trying to play an mp3. Not entirely sure what's going on here, but here's what I can say for sure:

- The episode I am trying to watch is Episode 13 of Libre Lounge, feed URL https://librelounge.org/rss-feed.rss
- The feed contains both audio/mpeg and audio/ogg files for each episode.
- Having gst-libav not installed will cause the ogg to be downloaded; having gst-libav installed seems to cause the mp3 to be downloaded as an m2a.
- The m2a still plays fine when gst-libav is uninstalled; it only causes a crash when attempting to change the speed while gst-libav is installed. 

Attached are the file in question (labeled 7.m2a for some reason, despite being Episode 13), as well as the GST_DEBUG=9 log. [log.txt](/uploads/a0f9caacc5251ff00cf52f92f9fcfde8/log.txt)[7.m2a](/uploads/4d9089e56ad3184b83f82886a00940c0/7.m2a)
